awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: An Inter-disciplinary Approach to Constraining Paleo-geomorphic Responses to the Eocene-Oligocene Hothouse to Icehouse Transition
awd_abstract_narration:
Rivers are the arteries of the nation and are vital as sources of water and recreation, and avenues of commerce. They are also bellwethers for change in the landscape. However, a question of fundamental importance for national interest is how river systems respond to major environmental changes. Predicting how changes in environmental conditions affect river processes, such as flooding and erosion, is critical for water resource management. This project uses knowledge of the past as a key to better inform the present through examining ~35 million year old sediments from an ancient river network in western Nebraska and South Dakota to quantify how changes in precipitation, vegetation and temperature in the past caused changes in river discharge and flood magnitude. These data, integrated with hydraulic models, will improve our ability to predict how rivers flood, sediment is transported and catchments evolve. Results of this work will have far reaching implications for understanding, modeling and planning for changes to river systems in the future. Three key broader impacts of this study include: 1) support of graduate and undergraduate students to develop interdisciplinary expertise; 2) sharing of data, methods and results as teaching data-sets on open-access platforms; 3) science outreach modules for children to explore 3-dimensional rock outcrops and animations from computational models. 

The goal of the proposed research is to reconstruct the coevolution of paleoriver and ecosystems dynamics with environmental change in western North America during the Eocene-Oligocene transition (EOT), perhaps the largest climate state change of the last 65 million years. This will be accomplished by integrating geochemical records of paleoclimate, sedimentologic indicators of river transport and deposition, and hydraulic-geomorphic models. To achieve the project goals a team of geochemists, sedimentologists and hydraulic engineers will develop an integrated approach to understanding how rivers respond to environmental change. Success in this cross-disciplinary approach could provide a paradigm shift in utilizing modern and ancient terrestrial geologic archives to quantify environmental perturbations that manifest in the hydraulics, morphodynamics and regional ecosystem responses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Scientific outcomes

We explored the impacts of environmental change on river landscapes in central North America during the Eocene-Oligocene Transition (EOT) approximately 33.9 - 33.5 million years ago (Ma), and focussed on the White River Group (WRG) deposits exposed in Nebraska, USA. During the EOT, global sea surface temperatures dropped by about 6°C, and the first permanent ice sheets formed in Antarctica. Despite many studies on climate change, tectonics, and volcanism from this era, the specifics of rivers, floodplains, and catchments remain underexplored.

We integrated descriptive and quantitative sedimentological constraints of river and floodplain hydrology at Denison University (DU) with climate reconstructions from organic biomarkers and soil geochemistry at University of Connecticut (UConn) to characterize how rivers responded to tectonic uplift, volcanism and long and short term climate variability from ~38 Ma to 31.6 Ma. Reconstructions of EOT river landscapes were used to inform and validate long timescale geomorphic models developed at Villanova University (VU; Grant EAR- 1844180).

After the final phase of mountain-building in the region, called the Laramide uplift, adjustment in the downstream gradients of rivers is recorded in the Chamberlain Pass Formation (CPF). Shallow, mobile, sand-and-gravel rivers changed to deeper rivers with less gravel in transport and relatively stable, inactive floodplains. In contrast to the thick sandstones deposited by the CPF rivers, the overlying Chadron Formation (CF) and Brule Formation (BF) are dominated by fine-grained floodplain deposits. We infer that increased fine-grained volcanogenic sedimentation during these intervals produced rapid sedimentation on landscapes with expansive floodplains and relatively few river channels. The transition from Late Eocene CF to early Oligocene Orella Member (OM) of the BF reflect enhanced seasonality and discharge variability associated with the onset of the EOT, and is marked by coarser floodplains that flooded often and rare channel deposits from ephemeral streams. Lower OM deposits (33.9 - 33.4 Ma) record up to ~10m of erosional relief, produced by erosion and deposition in rivers responding to alternating wet and dry periods during the early EOT ~300,000-year phase of relatively rapid cooling. Younger OM deposits (33.4 - 31.6 Ma) are flat-lying floodplain mudstones and sandstones, and no significant erosional surfaces are observed. We infer that these strata continue to record frequent flooding tied to significant seasonality associated with EOT cooling and drying, high volcanogenic sediment loads, and a relatively stable climate system after the end of the initial phase of rapid cooling.

The project resulted in 17 conference presentations including 7 presentations by undergraduate students; an additional 6 presentations were delivered by partner institutions Villanova University and Temple University. 

Results are presented in 3 research manuscripts:

  1. Anjali M. Fernandes, Michael T. Hren, Virginia B. Smith, Arvind Singh, Dennis O. Terry, Jr., River Floodplains, Organic Carbon, and Climate: The Impact of River Dynamics on the Biogeochemical Climate Record (https://doi.org/10.31223/X5ZT3H)

  2. Anjali M. Fernandes, Michael T Hren, Queenie Chang, Virginia B. Smith, Baylee McGinnis, Dennis O. Terry, Jr., David B. Luffman, Mia M. Rhodes, Yvette Eley, Madelyn A. Kurtz, Sarah E. Heithaus, Paleohydrology of North American Catchments and Rivers at the Onset of the Eocene-Oligocene Climate Transition: Reconstructions from Fluvial Strata of the White River Group, Toadstool Geologic Park, Nebraska (https://doi.org/10.31223/X5241S)

  3. Queenie Chang, Anjali M. Fernandes, Michael T. Hren, Virginia B. Smith, Dennis O. Terry, Jr., David B. Luffman, Mia M. Rhodes, Madelyn A. Kurtz, River Landscapes during the Eocene Oligocene Climate Transition in Central North America (https://doi.org/10.31223/X5NX2C)

Three additional DU-UConn-led manuscripts are in preparation, and several collaborative works with our partner institutions are expected.

Broader impacts outcomes

At DU, this grant supported a total of 13 undergraduate students through  research experiences, including 8 who identified as women (1 Black, 1 Latinx, 3 Asian-American, 4 Caucasian, 2LGBTQ+, 2 first generation college attendees) and 4 who identified as men (Caucasian), since January 2021. Students were trained in outdoor data collection, lab analyses, proposal writing, and/or research presentations at national meetings. The grant also supported career-development of a post-doctoral researcher and an early career professor (2 women; 1 South Asian, 1 Asian-American). At UConn, this grant supported 2 undergraduate thesis students (Caucasian men) and a M. S. student (Caucasian woman). Students graduated from both programs are currently in the STEM workforce, or pursuing higher studies in Earth/Environmental Sciences. Methods and data developed for this project support teaching materials in Earth Science curriculum; links to the source data are included in the supplementary data with submitted manuscripts.
